questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after his head was hit with a bat during a baseball game. His teammates state that he was unresponsive after the incident but regained consciousness after 15 minutes. The patient initially refused to go to the hospital and sat on the bench for the remainder of the game. He initially appeared fine but became increasingly confused. He appears lethargic but opens his eyes to loud verbal commands. He is oriented to person and place. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 148/87 mm Hg. Examination shows an area of soft-tissue swelling over the left temporal region. A CT scan of the head shows a biconvex lens-shaped hyperdensity in the left frontotemporal region. After returning from the CT scan, the patient only opens his eyes to painful stimuli and responds to questions with incomprehensible sounds. He withdraws from painful stimuli. On repeat examination, the left pupil is 6 mm in diameter and reacts minimally to light. The right pupil is 3 mm in diameter and reacts normally to light. His respiratory rate is 10/min and he is intubated in the emergency department. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsurgical management, which includes serial head CT scans and neurological observation, may be considered in experienced neurosurgical centers for patients with small acute epidural hematomas (hematoma volume < 30 cm3) with a GCS > 9, if focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiplegia, cranial nerve palsy) are absent. This patient displays signs and symptoms of severely elevated intracranial pressure (anisocoria, decrease in respiratory rate) with imminent brain herniation. Urgent treatment is indicated to prevent further neurological deterioration, permanent brain damage, and death.

B) INCORRECT:

Administration of hypertonic (not hypotonic) saline can help to acutely lower elevated intracranial pressure and may be used as an adjuvant treatment in this patient. It establishes an osmolarity gradient, which draws water from the interstitium across the blood-brain barrier into the vessels and thereby decreases the intracranial pressure. Hypotonic saline would do just the opposite, further increasing intracranial pressure by drawing water into the brain, and is, therefore, contraindicated in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone is the primary corticosteroid used to treat brain edema and elevated intracranial pressure, e.g., in a patient with a brain tumor or bacterial meningitis. However, glucocorticoids (including dexamethasone) should not be used in patients with severe traumatic head injuries because they are associated with a significant increase in acute mortality. This patient has an expanding epidural hematoma with imminent brain herniation, which warrants a more aggressive treatment approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) is indicated in numerous neurological conditions, e.g., in patients suspected of subarachnoid hemorrhage with a negative CT. However, LP is contraindicated in any patient with suspected intracranial pressure, because the sudden loss of spinal fluid may trigger brainstem herniation. In this patient, who has obvious signs of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., anisocoria, Cushing reflex), an LP is contraindicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Emergency hematoma evacuation through a burr hole may be used to treat acute epidural hematoma. However, it is only the second-line treatment because it does not always allow complete evacuation of the hematoma and/or ligation of the bleeding meningeal vessel. In centers with limited neurosurgical expertise, burr hole evacuation is an acceptable alternative, because it can be performed by general surgeons, but generally it is not the preferred surgical approach.

F) CORRECT:

First-line treatment for patients with an epidural hematoma is urgent craniotomy and hematoma evacuation to prevent brain herniation resulting from the progressive increase in intracranial pressure (ICP). This procedure also helps identify and ligate the injured vessel. A delay in surgical treatment is associated with a worsening prognosis. This patient's rapid decline in consciousness (GCS is 8 following the CT scan), decrease in respiratory rate, and anisocoria suggest ongoing compression of the brain that should prompt immediate decompressive craniotomy. Further management includes countering the elevated ICP using head elevation, hyperventilation, and/or osmotic diuresis with mannitol or hyperosmotic saline solution.
Image Description:

CT head (axial section; noncontrast)

An epidural hematoma is visible as a solitary biconvex hyperdense lesion in the left frontotemporal region (green overlay), causing a midline shift to the contralateral side (indicated by lines and arrows). The soft tissue of the scalp overlying the lesion also appears hyperdense, indicating a scalp hematoma (red overlay).

G) INCORRECT:

Although MRI has a higher sensitivity than CT, it is not the imaging test of choice for patients with epidural hematoma. It takes much longer than a CT scan, making it unsuitable for unstable patients, such as this one. This patient's CT confirms acute epidural hematoma, and further diagnostics would unnecessarily delay treatment. Urgent treatment is indicated to prevent further neurological deterioration, permanent brain damage, and death.
questions.hint: In a patient with head trauma, a lucid interval followed by a neurological decline together with a biconvex lens-shaped hyperdensity on CT scan is consistent with an expanding epidural hematoma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While the remainder of the physical examination is being performed, the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of ischemic stroke depend on the affected area of the brain. Patients typically present with focal neurological deficits like hemiparesis and have risk factors such as diabetes or hypercholesterolemia. Additionally, seizures, elevated ICP, and a traumatic origin are all unusual findings for ischemic stroke.

B) INCORRECT:

Onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma (SDH) depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. In acute onset, the patient may also present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma. In rare cases, patients may also experience a lucid interval. However, the temporary recovery of consciousness is more commonly associated with a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intracerebral hemorrhage typically results from a spontaneous (i.e., nontraumatic) rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls, e.g., in chronic hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Patients present with headache and focal neurologic deficits, such as hemiparesis. Rarely, it is caused by a head trauma with direct damage of the vessel. Signs of increased ICP and a lucid interval are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Subarachnoidal hemorrhages may occur spontaneously or after head trauma. Patients typically present with sudden, excruciating headaches (thunderclap headache), meningism, and loss of consciousness. While this patient also experienced headache and a loss of consciousness, signs of elevated ICP and the momentary recovery of consciousness point to another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) usually presents with chronic headaches and visual symptoms (e.g., transient loss of vision) that gradually worsens over months to years. It is not associated with head trauma. While this patient is in the peak age group of IIH (15–45 years of age), she developed her symptoms rapidly following a traumatic event and does not have any visual symptoms.

F) CORRECT:

An epidural hematoma should be suspected in any patient with severe head trauma and initial loss of consciousness that is followed by a lucid interval and then soon after by a new decline in mental status with signs of elevated ICP. The lucid interval represents the time it takes for blood to accumulate in the epidural space before compressing the brain and resulting in clinical deterioration. The length of the lucid interval depends on the severity of the trauma and the intensity of the bleeding and is typically shorter in patients with bleeding from the meningeal arteries compared to patients who bleed from a torn bridging vein (as seen with subdural hematomas).
Image Description:

Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.
questions.hint: This patient had a brief recovery of consciousness (lucid interval) after experiencing head trauma, but now has signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), including nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, and Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea). All of these features suggest intracranial hemorrhage most likely due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after being struck by a car while walking on the sidewalk. His wife reports that he was unconscious for approximately 5 minutes and has vomited three times. He has a history of hypertension treated with lisinopril. On arrival, he appears drowsy. He is oriented to person but not to time and place. His pulse is 65/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Examination shows an area of soft-tissue swelling over the left temporal region. The left pupil is fixed and dilated. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the right upper and 4/5 in the right lower extremities, 5/5 in the left upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

choices.text: Embolism in the middle cerebral artery
Rupture of the middle meningeal artery
Bleeding from an intraventricular arteriovenous malformation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Saccular aneurysm rupture leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which can manifest with altered mental status, vomiting, and focal neurologic deficits, all of which are seen here. Furthermore, this patient's hypertension puts him at increased risk of developing SAH. However, SAH usually occurs spontaneously, not following head trauma, and typically manifests with a sudden, severely painful (thunderclap) headache. Moreover, this patient's CT scan does not show blood in the subarachnoid space, as would be expected in SAH.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.

B) INCORRECT:

Tearing of the bridging veins that cross the subdural space leads to subdural hematoma (SDH). Acute SDH can manifest with altered mental status, focal neurological signs (e.g., contralateral hemiparesis), vomiting, and pupillary abnormalities (e.g., fixed dilated pupils) following head trauma, similar to what is seen here. However, in SDH, a crescent-shaped, concave hematoma that crosses suture lines would be seen on CT scan.
Image Description:

CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of trauma

A large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

C) INCORRECT:

An embolism in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) would cause an ischemic stroke, which can manifest with focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis), altered mental status, and vomiting, all of which are seen here. Furthermore, this patient's hypertension puts him at increased risk of developing this condition. However, a CT scan would most likely show a hyperdense occluded MCA (hyperdense MCA sign) and a hypodense parenchymal lesion. The CT scan could also show no abnormalities (e.g., if performed early after the onset of symptoms or in small strokes or brainstem strokes).
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

D) CORRECT:

Most cases of EDH are traumatic, resulting from a head injury that leads to rupture of the middle meningeal artery, which lies in close proximity to the skull and dura mater. Patients with EDH typically present with an initial loss of consciousness immediately after trauma, as seen in this patient. This might be followed by a lucid interval in which the patient regains consciousness before a rapid neurological decline and onset of symptoms caused by increased intracranial pressure due to hematoma expansion, including contralateral focal neurologic deficits (e.g., contralateral hemiparesis), pupillary abnormalities (e.g., anisocoria with ipsilateral mydriasis, fixed dilated pupils), and signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., altered mental status, vomiting).

EDH and traumatic acute subdural hematoma have similar clinical manifestations and are indistinguishable without neuroimaging. However, treatment is often the same for both (i.e., surgical decompression).
Image Description:

Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.

E) INCORRECT:

Although primary intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is relatively rare (in contrast to secondary IVH resulting from ventricular extension of ICH or SAH), arteriovenous malformations are a common cause of this condition. Primary IVH can manifest with vomiting and altered mental status, both of which are seen here. However, patients with primary IVH typically present with an abrupt headache. Moreover, focal neurological deficits are rare and, when present, usually involve cranial nerves. Finally, CT scan would show blood within the ventricular system.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A large hematoma (red overlay) accompanied by edema (green overlay) and mild mass effect involves the right basal ganglia and cerebral parenchyma. A small left basal ganglia hemorrhage (blue overlay) is also present. Hemorrhage has extended into the ventricular system (yellow overlay). Portions of a right ventricular stent (white arrows) are visible.

F) INCORRECT:

Damage to the lenticulostriate arteries causes intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and is most often a consequence of hypertension. Patients with ICH can present with focal neurologic deficits, altered mental status, and vomiting, all of which are seen here. However, CT scan would show an intraparenchymal hyperdense lesion (most commonly in the area of the basal ganglia), surrounded by hypodense edema.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertension

Hyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).

The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.

1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a biconvex, hyperdense lesion in the left frontotemporal region limited by the skull suture line, which suggests an epidural hematoma (EDH).

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college soccer player presents to the emergency department (ED) 30 minutes after a head-to-head collision with another player on the field. She reports that she lost consciousness for 2 to 3 minutes after the event but did not vomit.
She is asymptomatic upon arrival in the ED but, during the first hour of observation, reports the onset of severe headache and photophobia. When asked to locate her pain, she points to her left temple. Her vital signs remain normal for her age, and her pupils are equal in size and reactive to light bilaterally. She is able to answer some questions but is becoming confused. She has full strength in all her extremities. During the repeat examination, she keeps her eyes closed and places her hands on her temples. She has one episode of emesis after this evaluation. She is given a dose of intravenous morphine but reports very little improvement in her pain.
A rapid head CT is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate neurosurgical consultation for urgent surgical evacuation
Administration of mannitol or hypertonic saline
Transfer to the critical care unit for observation
Urgent brain MRI for further characterization of the lesion
Education about strict graduated return-to-play criteria, and discharge with close follow-up

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's neurologic status is declining quickly in the setting of head trauma, and her CT scan shows an epidural hematoma (EDH).

EDHs often have a traumatic origin but occur in only 1% to 2% of all patients with head injuries. The mechanism of injury is often relatively low in intensity.

EDH is frequently caused by a lesion of the medial meningeal artery. Such arterial bleeding leads to rapid accumulation of blood in the epidural space, thereby compressing the underlying brain parenchyma and potentially causing symptoms such as headache, vomiting, and a decrease in consciousness. Symptoms usually occur more quickly than those associated with venous hemorrhage. Many patients with EDH initially have a normal examination (during the "lucid interval") and then quickly deteriorate neurologically during observation, over the course of minutes to hours. The typical CT finding is a sharply localized fluid collection that has a unilateral, lenticular (lens-like) shape adjacent to the skull. There is an associated overlying skull fracture in 60% to 80% of cases.

A neurosurgeon should be consulted immediately in all cases of EDH. Patients with EDH who have a depressed level of consciousness, focal neurologic findings, pupillary abnormalities, or signs of increased intracranial pressure require urgent surgical intervention; those who receive such intervention typically have an excellent prognosis. If the hematoma is not evacuated and the bleeding lesion is not addressed quickly, uncal herniation can occur. The risks from an undiagnosed or untreated epidural hematoma are substantial.

Key learning point: In a patient with head trauma, declining neurologic status, and CT evidence of an epidural hematoma, the most appropriate next step in management is to obtain a neurosurgical evaluation for urgent surgical evacuation.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient requires immediate surgical intervention, and the increased intracranial pressure will not be adequately treated with mannitol or hypertonic saline.

C) INCORRECT:

In very rare instances, a small EDH can be managed conservatively with very close inpatient observation and nonsurgical care, but that approach would be inappropriate in this case; it is recommended only for patients with a very small EDH (volume <30 mL and thickness <2 cm on CT), no focal neurologic deficits, and a normal level of consciousness.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an MRI would delay surgical evacuation in this patient and would not provide useful information beyond what the CT has already shown.

E) INCORRECT:

Graduated return-to-play instructions and close follow-up are indicated for patients with an uncomplicated concussion, not bleeding.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle and hitting her head on the sidewalk 1 hour ago. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has a headache and she has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. Her vital signs reveal hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While the remainder of the physical examination is being performed, the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma (SDH) depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. The length of the lucid interval depends on the severity of the trauma and the intensity of the bleeding and is typically shorter in patients with bleeding from the meningeal arteries compared to patients who bleed from a torn bridging vein (as seen with subdural hematomas).

The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.

If the hematoma is not evacuated and the bleeding lesion is not addressed quickly, uncal herniation can occur. The risks from an undiagnosed or untreated epidural hematoma are substantial.

Key learning point: In a patient with head trauma, declining neurologic status, and CT evidence of an epidural hematoma, the most appropriate next step in management is to obtain a neurosurgical evaluation for urgent surgical evacuation.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient requires immediate surgical intervention, and the increased intracranial pressure will not be adequately treated with mannitol or hypertonic saline.

C) INCORRECT:

In very rare instances, a small EDH can be managed conservatively with very close inpatient observation and nonsurgical care, but that approach would be inappropriate in this case; it is recommended only for patients with a very small EDH (volume <30 mL and thickness <2 cm on CT), no focal neurologic deficits, and a normal level of consciousness.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an MRI would delay surgical evacuation in this patient and would not provide useful information beyond what the CT has already shown.

E) INCORRECT:

Graduated return-to-play instructions and close follow-up are indicated for patients with an uncomplicated concussion, not bleeding.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a skateboarding accident. He was not wearing protective headgear and collided with a concrete barrier. On arrival, he is alert but complains of a severe headache. Witnesses report he lost consciousness momentarily at the scene but improved after a few minutes. Over the next hour, he develops confusion and repeated vomiting. Physical examination reveals a fixed, dilated right pupil (see report).


Heart rate
82/min


Blood pressure
125/80 mmHg


CT scan of the head: Lens-shaped hyperdensity confined to the temporal region
Which vessel is most likely injured based on these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The superior sagittal sinus is a dural venous sinus along the midline, and its injury is associated with midline skull fractures, resulting in venous bleeding with a crescent-shaped hyperdensity on CT. The lens-shaped hyperdensity and clinical features in this case indicate an epidural hematoma, typically from arterial bleeding.

B) CORRECT:

Epidural hematomas typically result from traumatic injury to the middle meningeal artery, especially at the pterion where the skull is thinnest. A fracture in this area can cause arterial bleeding between the dura and the skull. Clinically, this is associated with an initial loss of consciousness, a lucid interval, and rapid neurological decline due to increasing intracranial pressure, evidenced by signs such as a fixed and dilated pupil and vomiting. CT imaging shows a lens-shaped (biconvex) hyperdensity, characteristic of arterial bleeding confined by skull suture lines.

Key learning point: Epidural hematomas are most commonly associated with rupture of the middle meningeal artery due to head trauma.
Image Description:

Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.

C) INCORRECT:

Bridging cerebral veins are typically injured in acceleration-deceleration trauma, resulting in subdural hematomas, which appear as crescent-shaped hyperdensities on CT that cross suture lines. The lens-shaped hyperdensity on CT and the clinical presentation of a lucid interval followed by neurological decline are more consistent with an epidural hematoma from arterial injury.

D) INCORRECT:

The posterior cerebral artery is part of the vertebrobasilar circulation, running along the inferior and medial brain surfaces, away from the typical site of lateral temporal trauma. Its injury would lead to different hemorrhage patterns. The lens-shaped hyperdensity on CT and clinical presentation suggest an epidural hematoma from middle meningeal artery injury.

questions.text: You are seeing a 27-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle and striking her head on the sidewalk 1 hour ago. She experienced a brief loss of consciousness for a few minutes immediately after the accident. She now reports a headache and has vomited twice in the past 30 minutes. Her vital signs show hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea. There is a bruise over the right temporal region. During the physical examination, she develops a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is given and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracerebral hemorrhage typically results from a spontaneous (i.e., nontraumatic) rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls, e.g., in chronic hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Patients present with headache and focal neurologic deficits, such as hemiparesis. Rarely, it is caused by a head trauma with direct damage of the vessel. Signs of increased ICP and a lucid interval are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Subarachnoidal hemorrhages may occur spontaneously or after head trauma. Patients typically present with sudden, excruciating headaches (thunderclap headache), meningism, and loss of consciousness. While this patient also experienced headache and a loss of consciousness, signs of elevated ICP and the momentary recovery of consciousness point to another diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma (SDH) depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. In acute onset, the patient may also present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma. In rare cases, patients may also experience a lucid interval. However, the temporary recovery of consciousness is more commonly associated with a different diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

An epidural hematoma should be suspected in any patient with severe head trauma and initial loss of consciousness that is followed by a lucid interval and then soon after by a new decline in mental status with signs of elevated ICP. The lucid interval represents the time it takes for blood to accumulate in the epidural space before compressing the brain and resulting in clinical deterioration. The length of the lucid interval depends on the severity of the trauma and the intensity of the bleeding and is typically shorter in patients with bleeding from the meningeal arteries compared to patients who bleed from a torn bridging vein (as seen with subdural hematomas).

Key learning point: Epidural hematoma classically presents after head trauma with an initial loss of consciousness, a lucid interval, and then rapid neurological deterioration due to arterial bleeding.
Image Description:

Most epidural hematomas (EDH) are caused by a rupture/tear of the middle meningeal artery secondary to a traumatic head injury, typically associated with a skull fracture. The resulting hemorrhage separates the dura mater from the inner aspect of the calvarium and accumulates within the epidural space. As the dura mater is tightly adherent at the skull suture lines, an EDH does not extend beyond the sutures. An EDH would be seen on neuroimaging as a biconvex hyperdense lesion that does not cross the suture lines.

E) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) usually presents with chronic headaches and visual symptoms (e.g., transient loss of vision) that gradually worsens over months to years. It is not associated with head trauma. While this patient is in the peak age group of IIH (15–45 years of age), she developed her symptoms rapidly following a traumatic event and does not have any visual symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient had a brief recovery of consciousness (lucid interval) after experiencing head trauma, but now has signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), including nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, and Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea). All of these features suggest intracranial hemorrhage most likely due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: You are seeing a 19-year-old woman who plays college soccer. She presents to the emergency department 30 minutes after a head-to-head collision during a game. She reports a loss of consciousness lasting 2 to 3 minutes after the injury. On arrival, she is asymptomatic, but within the first hour of observation, she develops a severe headache and photophobia, localizing the pain to her left temple. She is able to answer some questions but is becoming confused and has one episode of vomiting after this evaluation. A rapid head CT is obtained (figure). Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate neurosurgical consultation for urgent surgical evacuation.
Administration of mannitol or hypertonic saline.
Urgent brain MRI for further characterization of the lesion.
Transfer to the critical care unit for observation.
Education about strict graduated return-to-play criteria, and discharge with close follow-up.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's neurologic status is declining quickly in the setting of head trauma, and her CT scan shows an epidural hematoma (EDH).

EDHs often have a traumatic origin but occur in only 1% to 2% of all patients with head injuries. The mechanism of injury is often relatively low in intensity.

EDH is frequently caused by a lesion of the medial meningeal artery. Such arterial bleeding leads to rapid accumulation of blood in the epidural space, thereby compressing the underlying brain parenchyma and potentially causing symptoms such as headache, vomiting, and a decrease in consciousness. Symptoms usually occur more quickly than those associated with venous hemorrhage. Many patients with EDH initially have a normal examination (during the "lucid interval") and then quickly deteriorate neurologically during observation, over the course of minutes to hours. The typical CT finding is a sharply localized fluid collection that has a unilateral, lenticular (lens-like) shape adjacent to the skull. There is an associated overlying skull fracture in 60% to 80% of cases.

A neurosurgeon should be consulted immediately in all cases of EDH. Patients with EDH who have a depressed level of consciousness, focal neurologic findings, pupillary abnormalities, or signs of increased intracranial pressure require urgent surgical intervention; those who receive such intervention typically have an excellent prognosis. If the hematoma is not evacuated and the bleeding lesion is not addressed quickly, uncal herniation can occur. The risks from an undiagnosed or untreated epidural hematoma are substantial.

Key learning point: In a patient with head trauma, declining neurologic status, and CT evidence of an epidural hematoma, the most appropriate next step in management is to obtain a neurosurgical evaluation for urgent surgical evacuation.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient requires immediate surgical intervention, and the increased intracranial pressure will not be adequately treated with mannitol or hypertonic saline.

C) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an MRI would delay surgical evacuation in this patient and would not provide useful information beyond what the CT has already shown.

D) INCORRECT:

In very rare instances, a small EDH can be managed conservatively with very close inpatient observation and nonsurgical care, but that approach would be inappropriate in this case; it is recommended only for patients with a very small EDH (volume < 30 mL and thickness < 15 mm on CT), no focal neurologic deficits, and a normal level of consciousness.

E) INCORRECT:

Graduated return-to-play instructions and close follow-up are indicated for patients with an uncomplicated concussion, not bleeding.

questions.text: A 28-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department after falling from scaffolding and striking his head on concrete 90 minutes ago. He initially lost consciousness but was alert and conversational with coworkers at the scene. His vital signs are stable with a Glasgow Coma Scale of 14. During evaluation, he becomes progressively lethargic and develops left-sided weakness. His right pupil is 7 mm and nonreactive, while his left pupil is 3 mm and reactive to light. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Arrange for emergent surgical evacuation of the hematoma
Obtain emergent CT scan of the head
Administer IV mannitol and prepare for intubation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic saline may help reduce intracranial pressure, but does not address the underlying mass effect. Medical management of increased ICP is insufficient for this clinical presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This presentation is classic for epidural hematoma: initial loss of consciousness, a lucid interval, and rapid decline with uncal herniation signs (ipsilateral fixed dilated pupil, contralateral weakness). Definitive management is immediate surgical evacuation, and survival depends on minimizing the time from neurological deterioration to operative decompression.

C) INCORRECT:

Emergency burr hole is a temporizing procedure that is only indicated when neurosurgical expertise is not immediately available and the patient has Glasgow Coma Scale ≤ 8 or signs of brain herniation.

D) INCORRECT:

CT scanning is the diagnostic test for epidural hematoma, but obtaining imaging in this scenario delays definitive management.

E) INCORRECT:

While mannitol may provide temporary intracranial pressure (ICP) reduction, neuroprotective measures alone do not address the underlying issue. Medical management of increased intracranial pressure is insufficient for this clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a head injury sustained during a soccer match. He reportedly struck the side of his head against another player's knee. He lost consciousness for approximately one minute but then regained consciousness, felt fine, and continued to play. About 90 minutes later, he developed a severe, worsening headache, began vomiting, and became increasingly confused. His blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg, pulse is 52/min, and respirations are 12/min and irregular. On examination, he withdraws from painful stimuli, and his right pupil is fixed and dilated. Which of the following is the most likely underlying structural injury?

choices.text: Laceration of the middle meningeal artery
Widespread shearing of cerebral white matter tracts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm causes a subarachnoid hemorrhage. This typically presents as a sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache and is not directly caused by trauma, although it can be precipitated by exertion. The specific post-traumatic clinical sequence of a lucid interval followed by deterioration is not characteristic of a ruptured aneurysm.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is typical of an epidural hematoma. The mechanism involves a direct blow to the temporoparietal region, which can fracture the thin squamous portion of the temporal bone and tear the underlying middle meningeal artery. The initial loss of consciousness is from the concussive force, followed by a lucid interval as the patient regains consciousness before the hematoma expands. The subsequent rapid deterioration, headache, vomiting, and confusion are due to the expanding arterial bleed causing a mass effect. The Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations) and a fixed, dilated pupil (uncal herniation compressing CN III) are ominous signs of severely increased intracranial pressure requiring emergent neurosurgical intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhage in the basal ganglia is a type of intraparenchymal hemorrhage most commonly associated with chronic hypertension. While trauma can cause hemorrhagic contusions, the presentation is typically with focal neurological deficits related to the bleed's location. The distinct lucid interval seen in this patient is not a characteristic feature of this type of injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Widespread shearing of cerebral white matter tracts describes a diffuse axonal injury (DAI), which results from high-velocity acceleration-deceleration or rotational forces. Patients with significant DAI typically present with immediate and prolonged loss of consciousness or coma from the moment of injury. A lucid interval is inconsistent with the pathophysiology of DAI.
questions.hint: The patient's clinical course, featuring a lucid interval after a head injury followed by rapid neurological deterioration and signs of increased intracranial pressure, is typical of a specific type of intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being struck on the right side of the head with a baseball bat. His friends state he was initially dazed but seemed to recover and refused medical attention. About an hour later, he developed a severe headache, vomited, and became progressively lethargic. On examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale score is 9. His blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg, heart rate is 50/min, and respirations are irregular. He withdraws from painful stimuli on his right side but shows no motor response on the left. His right pupil is 5 mm and nonreactive, while the left is 3 mm and reactive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for an epidural hematoma. The mechanism of a direct blow to the temporoparietal region often fractures the temporal bone and lacerates the underlying middle meningeal artery. The initial loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval and subsequent rapid decline, is pathognomonic. The arterial bleeding leads to a rapidly expanding hematoma, causing a swift increase in intracranial pressure. This is evidenced by Cushing's triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations) and signs of uncal herniation, including the ipsilateral blown pupil (cranial nerve III compression) and contralateral hemiparesis. A non-contrast head CT would show a biconvex (lentiform) hyperdensity that does not cross suture lines.

B) INCORRECT:

This injury is caused by high-velocity acceleration-deceleration or rotational forces, leading to widespread axonal shearing. It typically results in immediate and prolonged loss of consciousness or coma from the moment of impact. A lucid interval is inconsistent with this diagnosis, which is characterized by diffuse, rather than focal, brain dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

This condition involves bleeding directly into the brain tissue, often from a cerebral contusion after trauma. While it can cause focal deficits and increased intracranial pressure, the classic triphasic pattern with a lucid interval is not a typical feature. The clinical presentation is more directly related to the specific location and size of the bleed within the brain parenchyma.

D) INCORRECT:

An acute subdural hematoma is plausible due to its traumatic etiology and presentation with neurologic deficits. However, it is typically caused by the tearing of bridging veins, leading to slower, progressive symptoms over hours to days. A lucid interval is much less common than in epidural hematomas. This condition is also more frequently seen in elderly patients or those with alcohol use disorder due to brain atrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

While this is a type of traumatic intracranial bleed, its presentation is typically dominated by signs of meningeal irritation, such as severe headache, photophobia, and nuchal rigidity. Focal neurological deficits and the classic lucid interval seen in this patient are not characteristic features of a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which involves blood accumulating in the cerebrospinal fluid spaces.
questions.hint: The patient's initial recovery after the injury, known as a lucid interval, followed by rapid deterioration is a classic finding associated with arterial bleeding between the dura and the skull.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling from his skateboard and striking his head. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness but was alert and oriented when the emergency medical team arrived. Over the last hour, he has developed a severe headache, vomited, and become increasingly lethargic. His Glasgow Coma Scale score is now 9. Vitals are a blood pressure of 165/80 mm Hg, a heart rate of 52/min, and irregular respirations. Examination reveals a fixed and dilated left pupil. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive management?

choices.text: Placement of an intracranial pressure monitor

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has a large, symptomatic epidural hematoma (EDH) causing life-threatening neurologic compromise. The clinical picture of a lucid interval followed by rapid deterioration, combined with signs of uncal herniation (fixed and dilated ipsilateral pupil) and Cushing's triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations), constitutes a neurosurgical emergency. The non-contrast head CT findings of a biconvex (lentiform) hematoma with midline shift confirm significant mass effect. Emergent surgical evacuation via craniotomy is the definitive treatment to decompress the brain, prevent further herniation, and reverse neurologic deficits. EDHs are most commonly caused by a tear in the middle meningeal artery from a temporal bone fracture.

B) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to acutely lower intracranial pressure. While it is an important temporizing measure in patients with signs of herniation, it is not the definitive treatment. This treatment provides a temporary bridge to definitive surgical intervention by drawing fluid out of the brain parenchyma but does not remove the underlying compressive hematoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with close observation and serial neurologic exams is appropriate only for small, asymptomatic epidural hematomas without significant mass effect. This patient is severely symptomatic, has a low Glasgow Coma Scale, and is showing signs of active neurologic decompensation and brain herniation. Delaying surgical intervention for observation would lead to irreversible brain injury and death.

D) INCORRECT:

An intracranial pressure (ICP) monitor is a diagnostic tool used to measure pressure within the skull and guide medical management in severe traumatic brain injury. However, it is not a therapeutic intervention for a large hematoma. In this case, the patient's clinical signs of herniation and CT findings of midline shift already provide clear evidence of critically high ICP, making immediate surgical decompression the priority over monitoring.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic saline is an osmotic agent, similar to mannitol, used to medically manage elevated intracranial pressure. While it can be used to temporarily reduce brain swelling while preparing for surgery, it is a temporizing therapy. It does not address the source of the mass effect, which is the expanding hematoma, and is therefore not the definitive management.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a biconvex, hyperdense lesion in the left frontotemporal region limited by the skull suture line, which suggests an epidural hematoma (EDH).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after striking his head in a skateboarding accident. He had a brief loss of consciousness but initially felt well. Two hours later, his roommate found him confused and vomiting. On arrival, his Glasgow Coma Scale score is 10. His blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg, pulse is 50/min, and respirations are 12/min and irregular. Examination reveals a fixed and dilated left pupil with right-sided hemiparesis. A non-contrast head CT demonstrates a lentiform, hyperdense collection in the left temporoparietal region. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

choices.text: Insertion of an intraventricular catheter for ICP monitoring
Placement of a burr hole for drainage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An intraventricular catheter is the gold standard for monitoring intracranial pressure and can therapeutically drain cerebrospinal fluid. However, in the setting of a large, symptomatic epidural hematoma causing herniation, the immediate priority is definitive management of the mass lesion. ICP monitoring is an adjunctive tool, not the primary life-saving procedure required in this scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used as a temporary measure to reduce acutely elevated intracranial pressure. While it would likely be administered to this patient as a bridge to definitive treatment, it is not the primary intervention. Medical management alone is insufficient to resolve the underlying problem, which is a large, expanding hematoma that is compressing the brain.

C) INCORRECT:

A decompressive craniectomy, where a large portion of the skull is removed and not immediately replaced, is a procedure reserved for medically refractory and diffuse cerebral edema. This patient has a focal, well-defined hematoma that can be evacuated via a different management approach.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a classic presentation of an epidural hematoma, typically caused by a tear in the middle meningeal artery after temporal bone fracture. The lucid interval followed by rapid neurologic decline, signs of critically elevated intracranial pressure (Cushing triad: widening pulse pressure, bradycardia, irregular respirations), and focal deficits (ipsilateral fixed/dilated pupil, contralateral hemiparesis) from uncal herniation constitute a neurosurgical emergency. The lentiform (lens-shaped) hyperdensity on CT confirms the diagnosis. An emergency craniotomy is the definitive, life-saving intervention to evacuate the clot, relieve mass effect on the brain, and ligate the bleeding vessel. Prompt surgical decompression is crucial to prevent irreversible brain injury and death.

E) INCORRECT:

Burr hole drainage is most effective for liquid hematomas, such as chronic subdural hematomas. An acute epidural hematoma consists of a solid or semi-solid clot of blood that cannot be adequately drained through a small burr hole. A larger opening via craniotomy is necessary to fully evacuate the clot and control the source of bleeding.
questions.hint: The patient's clinical features of lucid interval, CT finding of a lentiform collection, and signs of uncal herniation point to a life-threatening intracranial bleed.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after being struck in the left temple with a baseball bat. He was briefly unconscious but regained full consciousness, reporting only a mild headache. Two hours later, he becomes increasingly lethargic with severe headache and vomiting. He denies any history of coagulopathy or medication use. Examination reveals a 3-cm laceration in the left temporal scalp and left pupil dilation that is sluggishly responsive to light (see report).


Heart rate
54/min


Blood pressure
165/90 mmHg


CT scan of the head: Lens-shaped hyperdensity along the left temporoparietal region
Which diagnosis best explains this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute subdural hematomas typically present as crescent-shaped collections on CT, crossing suture lines due to venous origin from torn bridging veins. This contrasts with the lens-shaped hyperdensity seen in epidural hematomas. Acute subdural hematomas are more common in individuals with brain atrophy or venous injury risk factors, which are not consistent with this young patient's focal temporal trauma.

B) CORRECT:

Epidural hematoma manifests following trauma to the temporal region, often involving the pterion, where the middle meningeal artery is vulnerable. This condition is characterized by an initial loss of consciousness, a lucid interval, and subsequent rapid neurological decline. The CT scan shows a lens-shaped (biconvex) hyperdensity, indicative of arterial bleeding between the dura and skull, limited by suture lines. Ipsilateral pupil dilation with sluggish reactivity suggests increased intracranial pressure and potential brain herniation, further supporting the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Epidural hematoma is characterized by a lucid interval followed by rapid deterioration, often associated with temporal bone fractures and middle meningeal artery injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Intracerebral hemorrhages appear as irregular hyperdense regions within the brain parenchyma on CT, not as a lens-shaped collection. They are often associated with chronic conditions like hypertension. The lens-shaped hyperdensity and focal signs, such as a dilated pupil, following temporal trauma, suggest an extra-axial hemorrhage rather than an intracerebral bleed.

D) INCORRECT:

Subarachnoid hemorrhage typically presents with blood distributed in sulci and cisterns, creating a linear or curvilinear pattern on CT. The lens-shaped hyperdensity seen here does not match this diffuse pattern. Additionally, focal neurological signs, such as a dilated pupil, are more indicative of a localized mass effect than the diffuse bleeding seen in subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting for 30 minutes. Forty-five minutes ago, he fell and struck his head, resulting in loss of consciousness for 1 minute. After regaining consciousness, he felt well for 15 minutes before the headache began. On arrival, the patient becomes rigid and his eyes deviate to the right; he is incontinent of urine. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and the rigidity resolves. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Acute insufficiency of cerebral blood flow
Bleeding between dura mater and skull

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracerebral hemorrhage typically results from a spontaneous (i.e., nontraumatic) rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls, e.g., in chronic hypertension or cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Patients present with headache and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis. Rarely, it is caused by a head trauma with direct damage of the vessel. Signs of increased ICP and a lucid interval are more suggestive of another diagnosis.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).

ROH: right occipital horn

B) INCORRECT:

A mismatch between production and absorption of CSF is the cause of idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which usually presents with chronic headaches and visual symptoms (e.g., transient loss of vision) that worsen over months to years. It is not associated with head trauma.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Left image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.

Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.

Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

C) INCORRECT:

Rupture of bridging veins causes subdural hematoma (SDH). The onset of symptoms in patients with subdural hematoma depends on the size, location, and rate of growth of the SDH. In acute-onset SDH, the patient can also present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma. In rare cases, patients may also experience a lucid interval. However, the temporary recovery of consciousness is more commonly associated with a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of trauma

A large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute insufficiency of cerebral blood flow causes an ischemic stroke, the symptoms of which depend on the affected area of the brain. Patients typically have risk factors such as diabetes or hypercholesterolemia and present with focal neurological deficits like hemiparesis, none of which applies to this patient. In addition, seizures, elevated ICP, and traumatic etiology are all unusual findings for ischemic stroke.

In malignant middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction, the most devastating form of acute stroke, complete occlusion leads to acute brain edema and elevated ICP, which may cause herniation of the brain, usually over a course of 1–5 days. Although this condition cannot be entirely ruled out in this patient, the absence of risk factors for ischemic stroke, the acute deterioration of symptoms, and the presence of a lucid interval make this scenario unlikely.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

E) CORRECT:

Bleeding between the dura mater and the skull causes epidural hematoma. This diagnosis should be suspected in any patient with head trauma causing loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval and subsequently renewed deterioration and signs of elevated ICP. The lucid interval represents the time required for the blood to accumulate in the epidural space to proportions great enough to compress the brain.

The diagnosis is confirmed by noncontrast cranial CT which shows a biconvex, hyperdense, sharply demarcated lesion located between the brain and the calvarium, limited by suture lines. Emergency treatment is necessary and involves surgical opening of the skull and evacuation of the hematoma.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)

A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

F) INCORRECT:

Rupture of a cerebral aneurysm is a potential cause of a subarachnoid hemorrhage that can also occur after head trauma. Patients typically present with sudden, excruciating headaches (thunderclap headache), meningism, and loss of consciousness. While this patient experienced headache and a loss of consciousness, the signs of elevated ICP and his momentary recovery of consciousness suggest another diagnosis.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Multiple areas of high attenuation in the basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and sulci (examples indicated by green overlay) are characteristic of extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage.
questions.hint: After sustaining a head injury and briefly losing consciousness, the patient experienced a brief asymptomatic period (a lucid interval), followed by signs and symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting, and seizure).
